author: M. R. C.

description: I don't know about the food they serve there, but the staffs were really nice.  Especially the girl who was making animal characters out of sourdough bread behind the window.  She was very nice to our little girls and even gave the girls samples to eat.  Thank you for that!
author: Easy S K.

description: Can't drive past this place without picking up a baggette. Yum!
author: nathaniel w.

description: I LOVE clam chowder!!  Its really close to where I live so I usually walk.  The staff is friendly and the place is well maintain.  Got to admit that they don't have as many choices as the other Boudin's but I'm not complaining since they have all sorts of breads, soup, sandwich, and coffee in one place.  My usual oder : clam chowder (they give u a small bread roll with ur soup), jalapeno cheese bread (snack for later), and a cup of coffee.  Soft bread and hot soup...can;'t complain!
author: Wendy K.

description: Every time we are in SF we come HERE! Gotta get our Boudin's fix. Agree, skip the mess at the wharf. And they have all sorts of breads and more. I like the sub rolls and as always the longs. We have crumbs all over the car as we head back to SoCal... but then it just gets mixed up with the sand anyway. Also they have great coffee, always fresh and nice and strong.
author: Curt A.

description: 5 stars for the smell of this place.  I can smell it blocks away. This is the Boudin where they bake the bread for all the other stores. The place to go for fresh baked bread, the coffee is not bad, only $1.00, free refills and always friendly service. If I wasn't on a low-carb thing I would be outta control...FYI they only serve 2 sandwiches here a one soup, the clam chowder, but every baked yummy treat you could ever imagine!
author: Dee D.

description: My friend told me that this place had the best clam chowder in the Bay area. I ordered the Clam Chowder Bread Bowl. The soup lacked substance, had maybe 2 pieces of clams and tasted bland. Honestly, Progresso Clam Chowder tastes way better than this.
author: David C.

description: Had the chowder for breakfast and the cheese scramble in a bread bowl at the cafe section (not the restaurant)...Great bread, great chowder, scrambles are ok, and the service was stellar...I'd come back again, seems like a fun little mainstay on the pier...
author: Benjamin B.

description: This place sucks!   I moved and this was the nearest place to me so I tried it out.  I was so disappointed.  They just have bread, one sandwhich option and clam chowder.  No other choices listed on their regular menus, no pizzas, no chili, no tomato cheese soup....I was terribly disapointed especially after ranting and raving about the caesar salad and fresh croutons..  There was hardly any seating except for outside with the freezing pigeons
author: Nikki W.

description: The bread here is so chewy crusty and still warm unbelievably fresh and yummy I suggest to make your own sandwich don't purchase there not so good, service a little slow when your rushing because you opted for the ten minute parking but overall a great place to get what San Francisco is so known for !!
author: Sara S.

description: Only thing worth gettin here is the clam chowder bread bowl and it's good but not GREAT.  I like Ivar's better.  But you can't beat it on a nice day in the city.  Worth the experience.
author: Lester A.

description: This is a really easy stop for those rush, rush mornings.  Parking is easy- a real plus for San Francisco!  There is never much of a line- another plus!  And the prices are very reasonable- a Grande size cup of French Roast will only set you back 1 buck- plus!  Grab a $1.95 chocolate scone or croissant to go with that coffee and it will still cost less than that fancy Starbucks drink alone.  You know everything is fresh since you see them baking away in the back of the small storefront.  There are 2 tiny tables out front if you have a few extra minutes, where you can enjoy this morning treat, while people watching.  Enjoy!
author: Judy K.

description: Fun little neighborhood bakery where you least suspect it. Tables outside for you to enjoy your clam chowder in a bread bowl. If I'm in the area and hungry, I know where to go. Nothing like the touristy Boudin on Fisherman's Wharf. The same great sourdough bread though.
author: Alexander G.

description:
their clam Chowder is phenomenon!
i just hope it has more soup in the bun tho.
nothing is better than having the chowder in a chilly nite!
author: Mutsumi I.

description: really neat retaurant. very fresh crab and great service. Erin the manager was amazing. She was friendly and made us feel like we were part of the family! Good job crew!
author: Ryan N.

description: had clam chowder in a bread bowl and Anchor Steam finished off with an outmeal cookie...  I liked the soup and delicious sourdough.  Lots of good sandwiches and other carbo snacks..
author: jed p.

description: This is not likely the 'best' spot in San Francisco to hit up some clam chowder, but its the best available to a wandering tourist.  I like this location because they will sell you an Anchor Steam along with your breadbowl, which is something that the Wharf location does not.  Strange.  Boudin is a great spot to grab a snack that won't destroy the palate between savory meals in this culinary superpower city.
author: Maurice G.

description: I know this is a chain, but their bread is so dam good. Nice and crusty on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside. Dip it in some nice clam chowder and you have a winner.
author: Sammy H.

description: I got the bread bowl, which to be honest, is not the healthiest thing you can eat, but it was so good. It's like one of those those "last supper" dishes for prison inmates that I could see myself choosing. The chowder tasted fresh and so much better than the canned ones I'm used to eating. Oh, the bread wasn't bad either. I had such a fun time cutting and dipping the bread in the chowder. The price point wasn't ideal, but I left with a full stomach, which is good.
author: Alex Y.

description: One of the things that i heard about San Francisco was that they make the best sourdough bread. So I went to the source of sourdough bread baking bliss. Ordered a clam chowder bread bowl and it was way better than the stuff they sell one block away in the street market. Very tasty and fresh. I only wish they would sell the sourdough bread started for baking at home. In two occasions i was told by the Boudin bakery staff and supervisor that they didn't sell it there, BUT, that the Franciscan restaurant next door did sell bread starter. And in both times i was told by the Franciscan restaurant they they've never sold it and have gotten multiple customers come in asking for starter. The Franciscan restaurant staff has no idea why the Boudin bakery has sent people there with the idea that they might sell it there. Other than that, the bread is good, not great.
author: Ray B.

description: My neighborhood may be overflowing with people, kinda dirty, hard to park etc.  But it also has just about everything I need.  Including fresh amazing sourdough bread just down the street.  Can't ask for more. This shop has most all kinds of fresh baked bread you would need.  I stopped buying sliced bread for the week and now I just go here and buy the fresh baked stuff.  Yummy Yummy!
author: cece S.

description: Dude... where else can you get DEE-licious croissants and $1 all you can drink coffee? Huh? Huh???
author: Andy A.

description: Love it here! Bread bowl and clam chowder, what's not to like! I would always come here, and get the soup and bread bowl to go and take it home! I love the crabcake sandwich here..., it is the best!
author: C M.

description: The last of the great San Francisco Sourdough Bakeries playing different roles for different people, tourists down on the wharf where they offer a huge warehouse type food operation that also bakes thousands of loaves of their great sourdough.  Then you've got this neighborhood store and airports, so it's hard to nail down their mission and plan, but they do some great things that are vastly different like the hollowed out sourdough round filled with clam chowder at Macy's, the sourdough and other sandwiches, salads, and sntree's at the Wharf and even loaves to take home or on a trip at the airport.  Diversity and a broad vision business plan make this bakery hard to nail down, but their bread is damned good.
author: Stu S.

description: You can sit down and eat Chowder in a sourdough bread bowl. This is the only place you can actually walk into that isn't a restaurant to sit and eat. You can't purchase meals from the vendors on the wharf and take it to these tables either. So if you need a rest come here and get some grub.
author: Robert L.

description: Croissant heaven, plus great place to pick up fresh sandwich rolls.  The only downside is that it's a tiny space, and it's often mobbed by the elderly and people with kids, which can make for a patience-trying wait.  But so worth it in the end!!
author: A W.

description: this place is kinda tricky because its looks more like a factory/distribution center than a nice little neighborhood bakery, but if you look closely on the side you'll see the door and find that it does have exactly what you were looking for. stoping by in the morning is always a good decision. they got all the necessities any bakery would provide and more. i recommend the chocolate criossants, and the huge foccacia that isnt too expensive. the place is mostly known though for their sourdough, which is tasty but not my favorite. if you really wanna experience this place its probably best to visit one of the other locations though.
author: Andrew D.

description: very good crabcake sandwich, fantastic bread, and i love their soup in the can... i always get it when im there. i recommend anyone to try this place out if they've never been
author: Mike M.

description: The food is certainly excellent. I wish the hostess would be a little more friendly. When asked if we could have lunch outside we were rebuffed as mentally retarding considering the heat outside. Apparently servers did not want to work the terrace on a warm day. Not much of a terrace there there, but I understand the concern. I just wished the hostess would have been less rude in communicating that info. Boudin's loss, cafe Gentil's gain.  We moved down the street and had a great lunch in a very friendly atmosphere. Boudin is of limit for us until they improve their greetings .
author: S B.

description: This one is different!  Ok, I know you've been to the one at the wharf but please, don't give up!  This one is waaayyy out in the Inner Richmond and there are no tourists believe me.  They bake the bread right there (I can smell it at my apartment and you can get just bread and leave or have lunch too.  Service is great, food is great and the bread just can't get any damn fresher than the ovens from the next room.
author: Misti L.

description: it's good. it's cheap, but i dunno...i just don't think it's 5 star worthy.  too small...i do enjoy the clam chowder bowls, though.
author: joseph k.
